articles.author: dixit patel
articles.description:
How It Works (High-level)
It checks Firebase Realtime Database to see if this device is registered ‚Äî if not, it registers itself with initial data.
Every 10 seconds, it queries Firebase for two flags: alert and screenshot.
If alert is set, it sends a Telegram message with login/system info, then resets the flag.
If screenshot is set, it captures the screen, sends the image to Telegram, then resets the flag.
This process repeats indefinitely, allowing remote monitoring and commands through Firebase and Telegram.
DixitGuard is a remote monitoring script project that allows you to monitor login alerts and take screenshots on a Linux machine. It integrates with Firebase Realtime Database and Telegram Bot API to send alerts and screenshots remotely.
Sends login alerts with user, date, hostname,‚Ä¶
articles.title: DixitGuard ‚Äî Linux Remote Monitoring & Alert Script

articles.author: Deniz G√∂kbudak
articles.description:
Originally published on Medium

Sharing here with some developer-specific reflections.
As a self-taught frontend developer, I‚Äôve spent countless hours learning, building, and... feeling stuck.
Progress isn‚Äôt always about technical skills. Sometimes, the real blockers live in our minds.
In this post, I want to share 3 mental traps that have slowed me down ‚Äî and how I‚Äôm learning to overcome them.
This mindset kills momentum. I‚Äôve wasted days thinking:
‚ÄúI can‚Äôt build this app until I fully understand authentication, deployment, backend structure‚Ä¶‚Äù
But the truth is: you learn best by doing.

Every project teaches you something new ‚Äî even if it‚Äôs messy or incomplete.

Start anyway. Clarity comes with action.
Comparison is poison.

I‚Äôve looked at Twitter, GitHub, and portfolios of other developers and thought:
‚ÄúI‚Äôll never catch up.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre younger, smarter, faster‚Ä¶‚Äù
But everyone‚Äôs timeline is different. Some learn full-time. Some have years behind them.

Your path is valid ‚Äî even if it‚Äôs slower.

You‚Äôre building something real. That already sets you apart.
This perfectionism trap makes every step feel like a test.
I‚Äôve stared at a blank file thinking, ‚ÄúWhat if I choose the wrong approach?‚Äù

But reality is: you can refactor, change, improve.
Progress is made through iteration, not perfect execution.
These mental blocks won‚Äôt disappear overnight.

But recognizing them is the first step to breaking them.
I still struggle with them ‚Äî but I‚Äôm learning to move forward anyway.

Every project I finish, every post I publish, every bug I fix... it weakens the fear.
If you‚Äôre stuck, remember: progress > perfection.
Have you dealt with these traps ‚Äî or others?

Drop them in the comments ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to hear how you navigate them.
‚úçÔ∏è Written by @denizgokbudak

Frontend developer sharing my journey with React, Next.js, and AI tools.
articles.title: 3 Mental Traps That Hold Developers Back (And How to Break Them)

Understanding the 10-year Treasury yield: Definition and  importance            
            
                
The 10-year Treasury yield is the interest rate that the US government pays to borrow money for 10 years.
When the government needs cash, it issues bonds called Treasury notes, and the 10-year note is one of the most watched. The ‚Äúyield‚Äù is the annual return you‚Äôd get if you bought that bond and held it until it matures. It‚Äôs expressed as a percentage, like 4% or 5%.
Think of it as the government saying, ‚ÄúHey, lend me $1,000, and I‚Äôll pay you back in 10 years with some interest.‚Äù That interest rate and the yield move up or down based on demand for the bonds, inflation expectations and the overall economy.
